issues.title: Mapping of Keys to Verification Methods and Relationships
issues.author: rodolfomiranda
issues.body:
The goal is to define a univocal mapping between the keys in the KEL and the `verificationMethod` property,  and the Verification Relationships `authentication`,  `assertionMethod`, `keyAgreement`, `capabilityInvocation` and `capabilityDelegation` properties of the DID Document. 

From @pfeairheller [presentation](https://keriworld.slack.com/archives/C0552BPRN5D/p1682704423143979):
* Verification Methods:
    * KERI public signing keys
    * Other keys committed to by AID
        * Keys derived from public signing keys (encryption)
        * Anchored in KEL (using cryptographic digest)
        * BADA (Best Available Data Acceptance) Policy
* Verification Relationships:
    * Authentication and assertion assigned to KERI public keys
    * Other types represented by key role BADA data

From [ietf-did-keri](https://github.com/WebOfTrust/ietf-did-keri):

> For each key K in the Key State, add a Verification Method to the DID Doc containing K and the appropriate type, with the ID of K being K's prefix form (alternatively, the ID could be an integer of K's index in the current signer list)

I think we need to start defining:
* How to identify other keys anchored in the KEL. Should a specific seal format be defined to cover all possible cases defined in the DID Spec?
* key Id generation for each key
* Mapping of BADA roles to relationships

issues.title: Mapping of KERI service endpoints to services
issues.author: pfeairheller
issues.body:
Currently we only have a mapping from a KERI service endpoint for an AID in the role of Witness and that is mapped to a service with type 'keri-mailbox'.  That needs to be updated and others added.

In addition, we need to add other roles to KERI to support external service types like DIDCommMessaging.  We should also define service types for all endpoint roles in KERI and submit a PR to add them to:

https://www.w3.org/TR/did-spec-registries/#service-types

comments.author: rodolfomiranda

issues.title: Consider where to put the AID
issues.author: pfeairheller
issues.body:
The current proposal for a new did:web-ified did:keri is to format the DID the same as did:web with the requirement that the AID be the last component of the path portion of the DID

So something like

`did:keri:<domain name>:<path components>:<aid>`

It was proposed that we should instead place the AID first in the did:keri DID as in

`did:keri:<aid>:<domain name>:<path components>`

We need to make a decision on this.

Worth pointing out in another issue there is a suggestion to rename did:keri to did:webs and in that event it might make sense to keep the formatting of did:web

Could a domain-free form such as did:keri:EFcrtYzHx11TElxDmEDx355zm7nJhbmdcIluw7UMbUIL still be supported? So for did:keri:id:..., either id is a CESR code (without dots) or it is a dotted domain?

Or let the did:web lookup be a hint and reverse it: did:keri:{SAID}:domain.tld:…

issues.title: Rename did:keri to did:webs
issues.author: pfeairheller
issues.body:
A useful analogy.  did:keri is to did:web what https is to http.  And there should be about the same level of effort to step up from did:web to did:keri.  Let's people start with the easy way, but people will quickly transform to using the secure way because they remember http/https.

Instead of **did:keri**, we call it **did:webs** and push that analogy. From a marketing perspective it’s better - not named for KERI, but powered by it. Clean slate in some circles.

comments.author: SmithSamuelM
comments.body:
So we will support three did methods?
- did:web
- did:webs
- did:keri


I think there should always be a did:keri because its recognized now and will gain more recognition over time. But having a more secure version of did:web that is a limited version of did:keri makes some sense also.  Not sure.

comments.author: pfeairheller
comments.body: Yes, that makes more sense to me.  All three methods, we are defining the last 2 here.  did:keri includes the did:webs approach but also the super watcher variant.  did:webs is just the variant with the domain name.

comments.author: pfeairheller
comments.body: So maybe we need a did:webs repo and all this initial work needs to go there.

comments.author: SmithSamuelM
comments.body: And if we are really successful did:webs will supplant did:web

issues.title: Define how to use metadata such as equivalentId to express that two DIDs identify the same subject.
issues.author: pfeairheller
issues.body:
With support for both did:web and did:webs coming from the same AID, we'll need a way to associate the two together.  Defining a consistent approach in the generation of the DID Doc is needed.  

Current suggestion is EquivalentID.

issues.title: Define semantics for anchoring the domain in an anchor/TEL to track control
issues.author: pfeairheller
issues.body: In the event that a DID controller loses control of the domain name in their DID, we need to define a mechanism for anchoring some form of transfer log into the KEL of the base AID to ensure cryptographic chain of custody to the resolution of the DID at its new location.

issues.title: Restructure specification to match new approach
issues.author: pfeairheller
issues.body:
The current specification is out of date and does not contain the key approach landed on recently.  Specifically, the spec needs to define:

- [ ] The relationship to did:web
- [ ] Support for exposing DIDs also as did:web DIDs
- [ ] How to structure DIDs
- [ ] Sections for how to generate the DID Doc from KEL, rpy, etc.
- [ ] The contents of the DID Resolution Metadata
- [ ] CRUD method definitions.

issues.title: Define the exact contents and structure of DID Resolution Metadata
issues.author: pfeairheller
issues.body:
A defining feature of this DID method is the inclusion of end verifiable KERI artifacts for the current key state and service endpoints.  This data will be returned in the DID Resolution Metadata and can be used any any consumer to verify the contents of the DID Document themselves (thus **end** verifiable).

We need to describe how the CESR artifacts that accompany all KERI messages (key events, rpys, etc) will be encapsulated in the JSON structured DID Resolution Metadata.  In addition, for each mapping of a KERI feature to a DID Doc feature, the artifacts from that KERI feature must be included in the definition of the resolution metadata.

issues.title: Describe the association to did:web
issues.author: pfeairheller
issues.body:
This section should describe how a particular implementation of a did:keri DID method resolver can (maybe MUST) support resolution of any AID as a did:web DID as well.

The API from did:web should be expose in the implementation that returns the exact same DID Doc (and only the DID Doc) as returned during did:keri resolution.  The endpoint needed can be found in the did:web specification.

pulls.title: Reference to Peer DID
pulls.author: rodolfomiranda
pulls.body: I'm not sure if a reference to Peer DID should go in the spec, but if we leave it, it should point to the [Method 1](https://identity.foundation/peer-did-method-spec/#generation-method) of the DID Peer Spec that use the genesis and patches.

pulls.title: Remove "Service" disclaimer
pulls.author: rodolfomiranda
pulls.body:
I think the following text should be omitted in the new version of did:keri:

>The following field is not a core field in a did:keri DID document: `Services`. The did:keri method is provided for interoperability for the purpose of using KERI to establish control authority of the current public keys associated with KERI identifier behind the keri:did DID. It is anticipated that KERI tunnel methods (eg. did:indy:sov:keri) will provide these features to enable addition interop.
